question_category.name: Default for Module 1
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Module 1'.

question.name: U3|Pre|1 Admin
question.questiontext:
Our program uses nonfiction texts with ELLs at all proficiency levels.

Consider: If yes, what types? If not, why?

question.name: U3|Pre|2 Admin
question.questiontext:
Classes in our program give learners practice with note taking while listening or reading.

Consider: If yes, what levels and what techniques do they use?

question.name: U3|Pre|3 Admin
question.questiontext: We give learners opportunities to compare information from multiple readings.

question.name: U3|Pre|4 Admin
question.questiontext: Learners in our classes listen to video clips, podcasts, mini-lectures, and others.

question.name: U3|Pre|5 Admin
question.questiontext: Instructors in our program use graphic organizers (Venn diagrams, mind maps, grids) in reading and listening lessons.

question.name: Matching the Strategies to Learner Needs: Meet Inez From Ecuador
question.questiontext:
Matching the Strategies to Learner Needs: Meet Inez From Ecuador

In Unit 1 of this module, we conducted a thorough analysis of Inez's needs (analysis of Inez's needs).

TASK: Review the analysis of Inez's needs and identify those related specifically to the development of the kinds of reading and listening strategies outlined in this unit.

  • What kind of nonfiction texts and authentic listening materials are you including in your curricula now that would help a learner such as Inez?
  • What could your program do to serve such learners?

question.name: Connections Between Research and Practice
question.questiontext:
Connections Between Research and Practice

Parrish and Johnson (2010) addressed the following:

  • The need for skilled workers
  • The language strategies needed
  • Examples of applying that to the classroom

Download reading here and continue to the reflection questions.

Â

question.name: Read and Reflect 1
question.questiontext:
Read and Reflect

Read Parrish and Johnson (2010) and record points you would like to remember. Pay particular attention to what they say about teaching reading and listening strategies and the importance of note taking.

How do ideas presented in this research brief relate to any concerns or needs of your program?

question.name: Read and Reflect 2
question.questiontext: To what degree is your program incorporating instruction in the areas outlined, in particular, the areas covered in this unit?

question.name: Read and Reflect 3
question.questiontext: What are some steps you can take to infuse your program with more nonfiction texts, authentic listening passages, and more strategies instruction?

question.name: Unit 2|Pre|4
question.questiontext: Academic language includes the complex language and higher-order thinking skills needed to thrive in both school and work settings.

question.name: Unit 2|Pre|5
question.questiontext: Academic language is both written and oral language.

question.name: Unit 2|Pre|6
question.questiontext: Technical vocabulary associated with a specific discipline is the most important vocabulary to teach adult ELLs.

question.name: U3|Post|1|A
question.questiontext:
Our program will use more nonfiction texts with ELLs at all proficiency levels

Consider: If yes, what types? If not, why?

question.name: U3|Post|2|A
question.questiontext:
We will give learners in our program more practice with note taking while listening or reading.

Consider: If yes, what levels and what techniques do you use?

question.name: U3|Post|3|A
question.questiontext: We will give learners more practice in drawing from and analyzing information from multiple readings.

question.name: U3|Post|4|A
question.questiontext: We will add listening tasks to our curricula using video clips, podcasts, mini-lectures, and others.

question.name: U3|Post|5|A
question.questiontext: We will include more frequent use of graphic organizers (Venn diagrams, mind maps, grids) for reading and listening in our curriculum.

question.name: U4|Pre|1|A
question.questiontext: Critical thinking cannot be taught to beginning-level ELLs.

question.name: U4|Pre|2|A
question.questiontext: We include a layer of critical thinking practice in our curricula.

question.name: U4|Pre|3|A
question.questiontext: Adult ELLs donât know how to apply critical thinking skills.

question.name: U4|Pre|4|A
question.questiontext: Our teachers think about higher-ordering thinking when they write lesson objectives.

question.name: U4|Pre|5|A
question.questiontext: We teach adult ELLs language to express complex thoughts.

question.name: U4|Pre|1|I
question.questiontext: Critical thinking cannot be taught to beginning-level ELLs.

question.name: U4|Pre|2|I
question.questiontext: I include a layer of critical thinking practice in all of my lessons.

question.name: U4|Pre|3|I
question.questiontext: Adult ELLs don't know how to apply critical thinking skills.

question.name: U4|Pre|4|I
question.questiontext: I think about higher-ordering thinking when I write lesson objectives.

question.name: U4|Pre|5|I
question.questiontext: I teach adult ELLs language to express complex thoughts.

question.name: U4|Post|1|I
question.questiontext: Critical thinking cannot be taught to beginning level ELLs.

answer.feedback: CT can be taught at all levels through the tasks and content we choose, and the questions we ask. We may not name them at the beginning levels the way we can we with advanced ELLs.
CT can be taught at all levels through the tasks and content we choose, and the questions we ask. We may not name them at the beginning levels the way we can we with advanced ELLs.

question.name: U4|Post|2|I
question.questiontext: I plan to include a layer of critical thinking practice in all of my lessons.

answer.feedback: Yes, you can!
You can
You can

question.name: U4|Post|3|I
question.questiontext: Adult ELLs don't know how to apply critical thinking skills.

answer.feedback: Not true. What learners may lack is the language needed to express those thinking skills. Also they may come from educational systems where CT is not rewarded in the classroom. Adult ELLs need to make decisions and solve problems all the time in their daily lives.

Not true. What learners may lack is the language needed to express those thinking skills. Also they may come from educational systems where CT is not rewarded in the classroom. Adult ELLs need to make decisions and solve problems all the time in their daily lives.

question.name: U4|post|4|I
question.questiontext: I will think more intentionally about higher-ordering thinking when I write lesson objectives.

answer.feedback: Hopefully, yes!
Hopefully, yes!

question.name: U4|Post|5|I
question.questiontext: I plan to teach adult ELLs language to express complex thoughts.

answer.feedback: Yes, we can provide instruction in the language needed.
We can provide instruction in the language needed.
We can provide instruction in the language needed.

question.name: U4|Post|1|A
question.questiontext: Critical thinking cannot be taught to beginning level ELLs.

answer.feedback: Not true. CT can be taught at all levels through the tasks and content we choose, and the questions we ask. We may not name them at the beginning levels the way we can we with advanced ELLs.
CT can be taught at all levels through the tasks and content we choose, and the questions we ask. We may not name them at the beginning levels the way we can we with advanced ELLs.

question.name: U4|Post|2|A
question.questiontext: We can include a layer of critical thinking practice in our curricula.

question.name: U4|Post|3|A
question.questiontext: Adult ELLs don't know how to apply critical thinking skills.

answer.feedback: Not true. What learners may lack is the language needed to express those thinking skills. Also they may come from educational systems where CT is not rewarded in the classroom. Adult ELLs need to make decisions and solve problems all the time in their daily lives.

What learners may lack is the language needed to express those thinking skills. Also they may come from educational systems where CT is not rewarded in the classroom. Adult ELLs need to make decisions and solve problems all the time in their daily lives.

question.name: U4|Post|4|A
question.questiontext: Our teachers will think about higher-order thinking when they write lesson objectives.

answer.feedback: Hopefully, yes!
Hopefully they will!
Hopefully they will!

question.name: U4|Post|5|A
question.questiontext: We can teach adult ELLs language to express complex thoughts.

answer.feedback: Yes, we need to provide instruction in the language needed.
We need to provide instruction in the language needed.
We need to provide instruction in the language needed.

question_category.name: Default for Pre-Unit Survey (For Instructors)
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Pre-Unit Survey (For Instructors)'.

question.name: I|Pre|1
question.questiontext: Most learners in my classes, regardless of level, have academic or career goals.

question.name: I|Pre|2
question.questiontext: Authentic materials (e.g. work documents, short articles, podcasts) are best used only at an intermediate level of instruction or above.

question.name: I|Pre|3
question.questiontext: A high school diploma or equivalency has only a small impact on potential earnings.

question.name: I|Pre|4
question.questiontext: There are gaps between what is taught in adult ESL classes and what learners need in order to be successful in postsecondary education.

question.name: I|Pre|5
question.questiontext: Adult learners with limited formal schooling may need 10-15 years of formal instruction to acquire academic and work readiness skills such as understanding complex texts or synthesizing information from multiple sources.

question.name: I|Pre|6
question.questiontext: Most learners can handle instruction in academic language, listening and reading strategies, critical thinking, and work with non-fiction texts and real-world data.

question.name: U2|Pre|1
question.questiontext: Teaching academic language primarily means teaching vocabulary.

question.name: Unit2|Pre|2
question.questiontext: Teaching academic language is mainly concerned with teaching "correct" usage.

question.name: Unit 2|Pre|3
question.questiontext: Adult ELLs who are not yet in post-secondary training need minimal practice with academic language.

question.name: A|Pre|1
question.questiontext: Most learners in our program/state, regardless of level, have academic or career goals.

question.name: A|Pre|2
question.questiontext: Curricula which include extensive authentic materials (e.g. work documents, short articles, podcasts) are best used only at an intermediate level of instruction or above.

question.name: A|Pre|3
question.questiontext: A high school diploma or equivalency has only a small impact on potential earnings.

question.name: A|Pre|4
question.questiontext: There are gaps between what is taught in adult ESL classes and what learners need in order to be successful in postsecondary education.

question.name: A|Pre|5
question.questiontext: Adults with limited formal schooling may need upwards of ten years of formal instruction to acquire academic and work readiness skills, such as understanding complex texts or synthesizing information from multiple sources.

question.name: A|Pre|6
question.questiontext: All adult ESL classes, literacy level to career pathways, should include instruction in academic language, listening and reading strategies, critical thinking, and work with non-fiction texts and real-world data.

question_category.name: Default for Components of "Rigorous" Instruction
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Components of "Rigorous" Instruction'.

question.name: What constitutes Academic Language?
question.questiontext: Select the items that you believe are examples of âAcademic Languageâ:

answer.answertext: Recognizing features of informational texts (headings, charts, graphs)

answer.feedback: Informal spoken language is what learners may acquire more quickly. They may be able to get by in day-to-day interactions, but may not have acquired the appropriate levels of formality needed in a job interview or to advocate for themselves with a landlord. Unlike informal language, which may use gestures, facial expressions, voice and pace to create a coherent message, academic sentences, especially written texts, tend to be more complex in their organization of clauses and phrases.

answer.answertext: Building on or challenging a partnerâs idea (Well, I think thatâ¦; Another way to look at it isâ¦)
Elaborating on an idea (Tell us more about..)

answer.feedback: Students may be able to find the meaning of a word in the dictionary, but may not understand the multiple meanings of words, especially in academic language. What about a word like âtable?â Table of contents; a table to display data; to table an issue.

answer.answertext: Using a professional register (colleagues vs. you guys)
Tier 2 vocabulary: high-frequency words used across disciplines (obvious, complex, establish, verify)
Discussing an authorâs claim (According toâ¦; In the text, the author statesâ¦)

question.name: What is âAcademic Languageâ?
question.questiontext:
Academic language is defined as ââ¦ the set of words, grammar, and discourse strategies used to describe complex ideas, higher order thinking processes, and abstract concepts.â (Zwiers, 2014, p. 22). Much of what is written on academic language development is in the world of k-12 education. It is considered the language of school, allowing ELLs to access and develop content knowledge along with their mainstream peers. What role does this play in adult ESL? A big one! Academic language should be defined in this context as both academic and professional language; it is language that can be used in work, community and school interactions.

Much of what we teach in adult ESL classes is âsocialâ English. In a typical adult ESL class, we often put more emphasis on basic communication skills in everyday situations than on interacting for academic or professional purposes. In those every-day settings, it's possible to communicate imprecisely or use casual language. A speaker or listener can repair misunderstandings by pointing to something to show what they mean. These are great communication strategies (and donât stop teaching them)! Will a student get by with informal, social language in a job interview, or when writing a report at work? There is a layer of âacademic languageâ that we can start teaching early.

Check your understanding of academic language with the next task.

 According to Robin Scarcella, âLearning academic English is probably one of the surest, most reliable ways of attaining socioeconomic success in the United States today. This variety of English entails the multiple, complex features of English required for long-term success in public schools, completion of higher education, and employment with opportunity for professional advancement and rewards.â Scarcella, R. (2003)

question.name: What are âLanguage Strategiesâ?
question.questiontext:
Connected to academic language are the actual strategies we employ actively while reading complex texts or listening to extended speech (directions from a boss, a presentation at a child's school, a lecture). We know from the research that skilled readers make use of a variety of strategies, some bottom-up (e.g. decoding words) and many top-down (e.g. using visual cues to aid in comprehension; drawing on prior knowledge). Similarly, skilled listeners listen selectively for particular words or phrases; they monitor their comprehension; and they use clues to infer the meaning of unknown words. These reading and listening strategies should be introduced and practiced long before learners reach advanced levels.

Typical adult ESL curricula do include reading and listening activities. We want to make sure that we pay attention to using more non-fiction texts, longer authentic listening passages, and that we explicitly teach and name strategies that learners can employ on their own outside of our classrooms. Of course there are reading, listening, writing and speaking skills. We will focus on reading and listening to understand complex language in this unit.

Check your understanding of academic language with the next task.

 There is research that indicates that the complexity of text a learner can read is the greatest predictor of success in college and careers (Pimentel, 2013).

question.name: What is âCritical Thinkingâ?
question.questiontext:
Critical thinking is the process of questioning and reflection that allows us to understand, evaluate, and solve problems and take informed action Critical thinking skills are vital for adults to thrive in their communities, in postsecondary education, and at work. Adult ESL learners have plenty of practice with critical thinking skills; most have made complex decisions for themselves and their families about their lives in the United States, their jobs, and their childrenâs schooling. They need the language of and practice with critical thinking in new contexts. For example, when questioning an assumption in English, we use phrases like these:

  • Thatâs true, but I wonder aboutâ¦
  • Why do you think that is?

To synthesize ideas, we might say:

  • It seems from our discussion thatâ¦
  • The main points seem to beâ¦

We need to teach learners this language and give them practice with it so that they can put their ideas into words.

Check your understanding of academic language with the next task.

It is a misconception that adults in ESL classes do not know how to think critically or employ higher order thinking skills. Most adult ESL students have made complex decisions for themselves and their families about their lives in the United States, their jobs, and their childrenâs schooling, and many speak two or more languages. At the same time, they may have had limited experience with formal schooling or have come from an educational system that does not focus on critical thinking or development of higher order thinking skills.

(Parrish and Johnson, 2010)

question.name: What are examples of effective Reading or Listening Strategies?
question.questiontext: Select the items that you believe are examples of effective skills and strategies:

answer.feedback: Reading aloud can have its place, but it may not lead to the use of very active reading strategies. Learners may struggle with pronunciation and not attend to meaning.Â  Consider when you have learners read a loud and for what purposes.

answer.answertext: Starting from the beginning of a text and reading word for word
answer.feedback: There are many things a reader can do before they tackle a text: preview a text and accompanying visuals; look at titles and bolded words; make predictions based on the title or section headings.

answer.answertext: Trying to understanding every word while listening
answer.feedback: When we listen in our own language, we listen selectively based on the information we need. When learners try to understand every word, they can lost very quickly. We need to give learners practice with listening for gist or specific information. We can help them recognize signal words in a short talk or lecture (e.g. enumerating ideas) or when someone is giving them directions (sequence words).

question.name: What constitutes Critical Thinking?
question.questiontext: Select the items that you believe are examples of âCritical Thinking Skillsâ:

answer.answertext: Replying to display questions about a story (Where does the character live?)
answer.feedback: Many of the questions in text books focus on facts and details without any analysis or interpretation. Changing the question âWhere does the character live?â to âWhy do you think the character chose to live there?â already gets a learner thinking more critically, even in a beginning-level ESL class.

answer.answertext: Analyzing relationships between components, items, and ideas
Using information to draw conclusions and make decisions
Recounting factual information from an article (80% of women work outside the home.)
answer.feedback: We may think that using authentic materials, for example articles with real data, automatically promotes more critical thinking.Â  The authentic text is a great start, but we need to get students thinking critically about what they read. How does that compare to your country? Why is it significant that more women work outside of the home now than before?

As we explore practices for teaching critical thinking in Unit 4, we look at sorting and categorizing tasks as an option.Â  Matching words and definitions doesnât usually go far enough or do much to promote critical thinking.Â  Instead, sorting a set of new words into categories does begin to promote some deeper thinking about the meaning or connotations of words.

question.name: U3|Pre|3
question.questiontext: I have learners compare information from multiple readings.

question.name: U3|Pre|4
question.questiontext: I have students listen to video clips, podcasts, mini-lectures, and others.

question.name: U3|Pre|5
question.questiontext: I use graphic organizers (Venn diagrams, mind maps, grids) in reading and listening lessons.

question.name: U3|Post|1
question.questiontext:
I will use more nonfiction texts with ELLs at all proficiency levels.

If so, what types and why?

question.name: U3|Post|2|I
question.questiontext:
I give learners practice with note taking while listening or reading.

What techniques will you try now?

question.name: U3|Post|3|I
question.questiontext:
I will have learners draw from and analyze information from multiple readings.

If so, be ready with some examples of what you could do.

question.name: U3|Post|4|I
question.questiontext:
I will create listening tasks to use while students listen to video clips, podcasts, mini-lectures, and others.

Consider: What topics would be suitable for your learners?

question.name: U3|Post|5|I
question.questiontext: I will use more graphic organizers (Venn diagrams, mind maps, grids) in reading and listening lessons.

question_category.name: Default for Part IV: Ideas for Administrators
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Part IV: Ideas for Administrators'.

question_category.name: Default for Pre-Unit Survey (For Instructors)
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Pre-Unit Survey (For Instructors)'.

question.name: I|Pre|1
question.questiontext: Most learners in my classes, regardless of level, have academic or career goals.

question.name: I|Pre|2
question.questiontext: Authentic materials (e.g. work documents, short articles, podcasts) are best used only at an intermediate level of instruction or above.

question.name: I|Pre|3
question.questiontext: A high school diploma or equivalency has only a small impact on potential earnings.

question.name: I|Pre|4
question.questiontext: There are gaps between what is taught in adult ESL classes and what learners need in order to be successful in postsecondary education.

question.name: I|Pre|5
question.questiontext: Adult learners with limited formal schooling may need 10-15 years of formal instruction to acquire academic and work readiness skills such as understanding complex texts or synthesizing information from multiple sources.

question.name: I|Pre|6
question.questiontext: Most learners can handle instruction in academic language, listening and reading strategies, critical thinking, and work with non-fiction texts and real-world data.

question.name: U2|Pre|1
question.questiontext: Teaching academic language primarily means teaching vocabulary.

question.name: Unit2|Pre|2
question.questiontext: Teaching academic language is mainly concerned with teaching "correct" usage.

question.name: Unit 2|Pre|3
question.questiontext: Adult ELLs who are not yet in post-secondary training need minimal practice with academic language.

question.name: U3|Pre|1
question.questiontext:
I use nonfiction texts with ELLs at all proficiency levels.

Consider: If yes, what types? If not, why?

question.name: U3|Pre|2
question.questiontext:
I give learners practice with note taking while listening or reading.

Consider: If yes, what levels and what techniques do you use?

question.name: U3|Pre|3
question.questiontext: I have learners compare information from multiple readings.

question.name: U3|Pre|4
question.questiontext: I have students listen to video clips, podcasts, mini-lectures, and others.

question.name: U3|Pre|5
question.questiontext: I use graphic organizers (Venn diagrams, mind maps, grids) in reading and listening lessons.
